text:
Andrew Bridgen fears 'diluted' Brexit after Leadsom quits Tory leadership race. By danjmartin | Posted: July 11, 2016 1 COMMENTS SHARES Andrew Bridgen fears 'diluted' Brexit after Leadsom quits Tory leadership race. X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (1) 
A disappointed Andrew Bridgen has said he wonders 'if politics will ever be in the possession of decent people again' after Andrea Leadsom quit the Tory leadership race. 
The North West Leicestershire MP had been the only one of his Leicestershire Tory colleagues backing Mrs Leadsom to become the next Prime Minister before she pulled out of the contest. 
Mrs Leadsom has announced she felt a nine week leadership contest was not in the national interest at this time. 
Her withdrawal also follows a row over and interview with the Times newspaper which suggested she had said she would be a better leader than rival Theresa May because she is a mother. 
Mr Bridgen said: "I am deeply disappointed. 
"Andrea Leadsom is a thoroughly decent and honourable person. 
"And as we all now know she is a mother and following the vitriol that has been heaped upon her and her family this weekend she has probably decided she doesn't want another nine weeks of it. 
"She has been treated appallingly by the media and her political enemies. 
"It makes me wonder whether politics will ever be in the possession of decent people again."

Mr Bridgen, who has said he feels the new Prime Minister must be a Brexit supporter, said: "I think our membership will feel cheated of the chance to choose between two visions of the future." 
He said he feared Mrs May, a Remain supporter, would try to 'dilute' Brexit despite assurances she has made. 
As the only remaining candidate Mrs May will take over in Number 10 from David Cameron on Wednesday. 
There are more than 1,000 Conservative members in Leicestershire and Rutland who will now not be among those who select the next Prime Minister. 
Tory Leicestershire and Rutland area chairman Leigh Higgins has written to Conservative associations in the wake of Mrs Leadsom backing out. 
He said: "This has been a very fast moving brief and I have made several representations on behalf of the membership. 
"I am sure some members may be disappointed upon not having a vote, however we should remember, and agree, our national interest should come first. 
"I firmly believe that we all should now unite behind Theresa May as being the only candidate for the leader of the party. 
As Conservatives it is the national interest we should always hold first as priority. 
Read more: UPDATE: Shares in Leicestershire companies rally after Leadsom quits 
"With Mrs Leadsom withdrawing from the race, declaring the interest of the nation as her reason, we should respect that and I would like to go on record to thank her for her generous statement. 
"Theresa May now commands the undisputed confidence of the parliamentary party and, I believe, the wider membership from the numerous calls I have taken these past few days."
